prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

head.headtext: Information Meriting Protection—During Course of Employment

para.paratext: During the course of employment, employees are strictly prohibited from using their employer's business information for personal gain. Broadly speaking, an employer is probably entitled to protect most information of a business nature while the employee remains in the employment relationship. This is not to say that every single fact about a business not in the public domain can validly be considered confidential business information. The courts will not, for example, protect information that is trivial or insignificant, even if it relates to the specific manner in which the employer's business is carried on.[1] The determinative issue is whether confidential information provides the employer with a competitive edge or an economic advantage in the marketplace. However, the disclosure of even insignificant information to a competitor with an improper motive would likely be considered a breach of the duty of fidelity.

Coco v. A.N. Clark (Engineers) Ltd., [1969] R.P.C. 41 (Ch.), at p. 48. See, however, Macri v. Miskiewicz (1991), 39 C.P.R. (3d) 207 (B.C.S.C.), supp. reasons 39 C.P.R. (3d) 486 (B.C.S.C.), revd [1993] 8 W.W.R. 46, 82 B.C.L.R. (2d) 126 (C.A.), where a simple process was classified as a trade secret. See also R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton, [1949] 2 D.L.R. 481, [1949] O.R. 303 (H.C.), affd [1950] 1 D.L.R. 601, [1950] O.R. 62 (C.A.); Canadian Javelin Ltd. v. Sparling (1978), 4 B.L.R. 153, 59 C.P.R. (2d) 146 (F.C.T.D.), affd 91 D.L.R. (3d) 64, 59 C.P.R. (2d) 165 (F.C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 24 N.R. 571n.
